funder.name: Bayerisches Staatsministerium für Bildung und Kultus, Wissenschaft und Kunst

abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Mayflies, stoneflies and caddisflies (Ephemeroptera, Plecoptera and Trichoptera) are prominent representatives of aquatic macroinvertebrates, commonly used as indicator organisms for water quality and ecosystem assessments. However, unambiguous morphological identification of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">EPT</jats:styled-content> species, especially their immature life stages, is a challenging, yet fundamental task. A comprehensive <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> barcode library based upon taxonomically well‐curated specimens is needed to overcome the problematic identification. Once available, this library will support the implementation of fast, cost‐efficient and reliable <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content>‐based identifications and assessments of ecological status. This study represents a major step towards a <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> barcode reference library as it covers for two‐thirds of Germany's <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">EPT</jats:styled-content> species including 2,613 individuals belonging to 363 identified species. As such, it provides coverage for 38 of 44 families (86%) and practically all major bioindicator species. <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">DNA</jats:styled-content> barcode compliant sequences (≥500 bp) were recovered from 98.74% of the analysed specimens. Whereas most species (325, i.e., 89.53%) were unambiguously assigned to a single Barcode Index Number (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content>) by its <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">COI</jats:styled-content> sequence, 38 species (18 Ephemeroptera, nine Plecoptera and 11 Trichoptera) were assigned to a total of 89 BINs. Most of these additional <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content>s formed nearest neighbour clusters, reflecting the discrimination of geographical subclades of a currently recognized species. <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">BIN</jats:styled-content> sharing was uncommon, involving only two species pairs of Ephemeroptera. Interestingly, both maximum pairwise and nearest neighbour distances were substantially higher for Ephemeroptera compared to Plecoptera and Trichoptera, possibly indicating older speciation events, stronger positive selection or faster rate of molecular evolution.</jats:p>
title: A <scp>DNA</scp> barcode library for Germany′s mayflies, stoneflies and caddisflies (Ephemeroptera, Plecoptera and Trichoptera)
